name: New York
fun_fact: Fun fact: Katz's Delicatessen has been serving pastrami since 1888 - over 135 years - and still hangs the iconic 'Send A Salami To Your Boy In The Army' sign from WWII when they shipped meat to soldiers overseas!

hero_dishes.name: Pastrami on Rye
hero_dishes.description: Hand-cut pastrami piled high on rye bread with spicy mustard
hero_dishes.origin_story: Brought by Romanian Jewish immigrants in the 1880s, pastrami became NYC's deli icon

hero_dishes.name: New York-Style Pizza
hero_dishes.description: Large thin foldable slices with hand-tossed crust, simple tomato sauce, gooey mozzarella
hero_dishes.origin_story: First US pizzeria opened in Little Italy by Gennaro Lombardi in 1905
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Lombardi's, Di Fara, Joe's Pizza, corner slice shops

hero_dishes.name: Bagel with Lox
hero_dishes.description: Dense chewy bagel with cream cheese and smoked salmon
hero_dishes.origin_story: Polish Jewish immigrants brought bagels to NYC in the late 1800s

hero_dishes.name: Dirty Water Hot Dog
hero_dishes.description: Street cart dog with sauerkraut and spicy mustard
hero_dishes.origin_story: NYC street vendor tradition since the 1860s
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Street carts throughout Manhattan, especially near Central Park

signature_drinks.name: Egg Cream
signature_drinks.description: Chocolate syrup, milk, and seltzer - no egg, no cream
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Classic soda fountain drink at Jewish delis

signature_drinks.name: Manhattan Cocktail
signature_drinks.description: Whiskey, sweet vermouth, bitters - invented in NYC

food_culture_notes: Dollar slice pizza is a NYC institution - $1 for a huge slice
Black and white cookies are NYC bakery staples
Halal cart food (chicken over rice) became iconic street food
Frankel's pastrami, egg and cheese on challah made NYT's '57 sandwiches that define NYC'
